page.title: 04LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: The earliest settlers in this area were the Belgae tribe from north west France in approximately 80 BC via the Thames estuary and the Lea. The Belgae established an important track along the valley of the Ver. The Roman invasion of Britain in 43 AD and subsequent development of an elaborate network has left its mark on the area. The Romans developed the Belgic track along the Ver valley as Watling Street. On the highest piece of ground between Watling Street and the Harpenden Valley a Romano-British temple or cemetery has been found. The damp forests and heath of the area were cleared over a long period. As late as the Norman Conquest most of the woodland still had to be cleared. The clearings made during the Middle Ages survive today as Kinsbourne Green, Wood End and Faulkener's End.
